values.description:
The `REGRESSION_1112_force_torque_model_removal` test has been [failing sporadically](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/31/testReport/junit/%28root%29/REGRESSION_1112_force_torque_model_removal/test_ran/):
~~~
275: [ RUN      ] Issue1112Test.Reset
275: [Msg] Waiting for master.
275: [Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
275: [Msg] Publicized address: 172.23.3.215
275: [Err] [RenderEngine.cc:682] Can't open display: 
275: [Wrn] [RenderEngine.cc:92] Unable to create X window. Rendering will be disabled
275: [Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:149] ServerFixture load in 0.2 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds
275: REGRESSION_1112_force_torque_model_removal: /usr/include/boost/smart_ptr/shared_ptr.hpp:653: typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type boost::shared_ptr<T>::operator->() const [with T = gazebo::physics::Inertial; typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type = gazebo::physics::Inertial*]: Assertion `px != 0' failed.
275: 
17/32 Test #275: REGRESSION_1112_force_torque_model_removal .........***Exception: Other  4.82 sec
~~~

I got a [backtrace](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/18ce60f9393f66f5c156) that implicates `ODEJoint::GetForceTorque`.

The fix is to check the inertial pointer before dereferencing it.
values.title: Fix sporadic failures of REGRESSION_1112_force_torque_model_removal

summary.raw:
The `REGRESSION_1112_force_torque_model_removal` test has been [failing sporadically](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/31/testReport/junit/%28root%29/REGRESSION_1112_force_torque_model_removal/test_ran/):
~~~
275: [ RUN      ] Issue1112Test.Reset
275: [Msg] Waiting for master.
275: [Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
275: [Msg] Publicized address: 172.23.3.215
275: [Err] [RenderEngine.cc:682] Can't open display: 
275: [Wrn] [RenderEngine.cc:92] Unable to create X window. Rendering will be disabled
275: [Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:149] ServerFixture load in 0.2 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds
275: REGRESSION_1112_force_torque_model_removal: /usr/include/boost/smart_ptr/shared_ptr.hpp:653: typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type boost::shared_ptr<T>::operator->() const [with T = gazebo::physics::Inertial; typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type = gazebo::physics::Inertial*]: Assertion `px != 0' failed.
275: 
17/32 Test #275: REGRESSION_1112_force_torque_model_removal .........***Exception: Other  4.82 sec
~~~

I got a [backtrace](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/18ce60f9393f66f5c156) that implicates `ODEJoint::GetForceTorque`.

The fix is to check the inertial pointer before dereferencing it.
summary.html:
The REGRESSION_1112_force_torque_model_removal test has been failing sporadically:

275: [ RUN      ] Issue1112Test.Reset
275: [Msg] Waiting for master.
275: [Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
275: [Msg] Publicized address: 172.23.3.215
275: [Err] [RenderEngine.cc:682] Can't open display: 
275: [Wrn] [RenderEngine.cc:92] Unable to create X window. Rendering will be disabled
275: [Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:149] ServerFixture load in 0.2 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds
275: REGRESSION_1112_force_torque_model_removal: /usr/include/boost/smart_ptr/shared_ptr.hpp:653: typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type boost::shared_ptr<T>::operator->() const [with T = gazebo::physics::Inertial; typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type = gazebo::physics::Inertial*]: Assertion `px != 0' failed.
275: 
17/32 Test #275: REGRESSION_1112_force_torque_model_removal .........***Exception: Other  4.82 sec

I got a backtrace that implicates ODEJoint::GetForceTorque.

The fix is to check the inertial pointer before dereferencing it.

values.description:
In general, `physics::Shape` and its child classes have accessors for dimensions, but not volume. This PR adds a `ComputeVolume` function that is accurately implemented for simple shapes (`BoxShape`, `CylinderShape`, `SphereShape`) and offers a bounding box approximation for other shapes. The `BoxShape`, `CylinderShape` and `SphereShape` unit tests also test `ComputeVolume`.

Upgraded to medium priority because this is a prerequisite for the `BuoyancyPlugin` (hydrodynamics DRC milestone).
values.title: Added Shape::ComputeVolume and implementations for simple shapes

summary.raw:
In general, `physics::Shape` and its child classes have accessors for dimensions, but not volume. This PR adds a `ComputeVolume` function that is accurately implemented for simple shapes (`BoxShape`, `CylinderShape`, `SphereShape`) and offers a bounding box approximation for other shapes. The `BoxShape`, `CylinderShape` and `SphereShape` unit tests also test `ComputeVolume`.

Upgraded to medium priority because this is a prerequisite for the `BuoyancyPlugin` (hydrodynamics DRC milestone).
summary.html:
In general, physics::Shape and its child classes have accessors for dimensions, but not volume. This PR adds a ComputeVolume function that is accurately implemented for simple shapes (BoxShape, CylinderShape, SphereShape) and offers a bounding box approximation for other shapes. The BoxShape, CylinderShape and SphereShape unit tests also test ComputeVolume.

Upgraded to medium priority because this is a prerequisite for the BuoyancyPlugin (hydrodynamics DRC milestone).

SVG transforms will come in a different PR

There's a test.
/build/gazebo/common/UNIT_SVGLoader_TEST

Alternativerly, you can CTRL-M (model editor) and add an svg file (look in /test/data/svg) and extrude a 3D link from a 2d shape.

values.description:
This is the first PR of Rachel Hwang's work for the path planner in Gazebo under the OPW program.

According to the [design document](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-request/13/adding-path-planner-design/diff), this PR is implementing the move plugin, which is used by the path planner to move the models without caring about the kinematics.
values.title: OPW Path planner: I model move plugin/example

summary.raw:
This is the first PR of Rachel Hwang's work for the path planner in Gazebo under the OPW program.

According to the [design document](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-request/13/adding-path-planner-design/diff), this PR is implementing the move plugin, which is used by the path planner to move the models without caring about the kinematics.
summary.html:
This is the first PR of Rachel Hwang's work for the path planner in Gazebo under the OPW program.

According to the design document, this PR is implementing the move plugin, which is used by the path planner to move the models without caring about the kinematics.

values.description: LightMaker.cc 's parent class EnitityMaker has built i support for snapping. This pull request simply makes LightMaker reuse that same code instead of rewriting it.
values.title: Snapping in LightMaker now resuses code from parent class

summary.raw: LightMaker.cc 's parent class EnitityMaker has built i support for snapping. This pull request simply makes LightMaker reuse that same code instead of rewriting it.
summary.html: LightMaker.cc 's parent class EnitityMaker has built i support for snapping. This pull request simply makes LightMaker reuse that same code instead of rewriting it.

values.description:
This is in preparation for supporting nested models.

Since we started manipulating links in the model editor, we've been relying on this hierarchy:

~~~ 
world > model > link > visual
~~~

So whenever we hit a visual, if we want to manipulate the model in which it is contained, we use `GetRootVisual` and for the link we'd do `GetParent`. But as we begin supporting more deeply nested visuals, we want to have more flexibility to get ancestors in different levels and easily support hierarchies such as:

~~~ 
world > model > ... > model > link > visual
~~~

In summary, we now have these functions: 

![ancestors.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1543323319-ancestors.png)

The new functions are being used in the model manipulator and model snap tools and shouldn't change their current behaviour.
values.title: Add functions to get a visual's ancestors according to depth

summary.raw:

Since we started manipulating links in the model editor, we've been relying on this hierarchy:

~~~ 
world > model > link > visual
~~~

So whenever we hit a visual, if we want to manipulate the model in which it is contained, we use `GetRootVisual` and for the link we'd do `GetParent`. But as we begin supporting more deeply nested visuals, we want to have more flexibility to get ancestors in different levels and easily support hierarchies such as:

~~~ 
world > model > ... > model > link > visual
~~~

In summary, we now have these functions: 

![ancestors.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1543323319-ancestors.png)

The new functions are being used in the model manipulator and model snap tools and shouldn't change their current behaviour.
summary.html:

Since we started manipulating links in the model editor, we've been relying on this hierarchy:

world > model > link > visual

So whenever we hit a visual, if we want to manipulate the model in which it is contained, we use GetRootVisual and for the link we'd do GetParent. But as we begin supporting more deeply nested visuals, we want to have more flexibility to get ancestors in different levels and easily support hierarchies such as:

world > model > ... > model > link > visual

In summary, we now have these functions:

The new functions are being used in the model manipulator and model snap tools and shouldn't change their current behaviour.

values.description:
This PR makes sure to also remove all stray visualization visuals when their parents are deleted. Thanks to @chapulina for the tests.

I also added a `VisualType` enum to `Visual`. This is convenient to distinguish between gui visuals, sensor isualizations, etc with entity visuals such as model and link visuals.

On fixing visual removal, I encountered a problem where the Event system tries to invoke member functions of deleted visual instances. This is mainly due to the fact that the visual is deleted before being removed from the event connections (which happens in the next `Signal` call) . A fix has been in place for this.
values.title: Clean up Visuals on removal and add Visual Type

summary.raw:
This PR makes sure to also remove all stray visualization visuals when their parents are deleted. Thanks to @chapulina for the tests.

I also added a `VisualType` enum to `Visual`. This is convenient to distinguish between gui visuals, sensor isualizations, etc with entity visuals such as model and link visuals.

On fixing visual removal, I encountered a problem where the Event system tries to invoke member functions of deleted visual instances. This is mainly due to the fact that the visual is deleted before being removed from the event connections (which happens in the next `Signal` call) . A fix has been in place for this.
summary.html:
This PR makes sure to also remove all stray visualization visuals when their parents are deleted. Thanks to @chapulina for the tests.

I also added a VisualType enum to Visual. This is convenient to distinguish between gui visuals, sensor isualizations, etc with entity visuals such as model and link visuals.

On fixing visual removal, I encountered a problem where the Event system tries to invoke member functions of deleted visual instances. This is mainly due to the fact that the visual is deleted before being removed from the event connections (which happens in the next Signal call) . A fix has been in place for this.

values.description:
This is another portion of the Windows port. Client applications were forced to link against the physics and sensor libraries because the application used `libgazebo.so`.

This pull request creates a separate `libgazebo_client.so` that can be used by client applications. It's now up to the client application to link against physics, if they need it.

[Jenkins is clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/113/)
values.title: Break out libgazebo_client from libgazebo

This pull request creates a separate `libgazebo_client.so` that can be used by client applications. It's now up to the client application to link against physics, if they need it.

[Jenkins is clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/113/)

values.description:
This pull request introduces the BuoyancyPlugin, which simulates the force opposing gravity exerted on an object immersed in a fluid. It also adds some checks and cleanup to LiftDragPlugin.

You can compare the effect of the BuoyancyPlugin on objects with different densities using [gazebo_models PR 140](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/140/added-submarines-of-varying-density) and the `underwater.world` included in this PR. One submarine will float to the top of the world, one will sink, and the other will stay afloat at a constant height (though it may spin due to its off-balance center of gravity). You should be able to get the yellow submarine to propel itself by using the left-hand menu to spin its propeller joint at a constant velocity. This is not due to buoyancy alone; the submarines also use the LiftDragPlugin.

The implementation uses Archimedes' principle, which you can read about on [Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buoyancy):

```
object density / fluid density = weight / weight of displaced fluid
```

where "weight" is the force on the object due to gravity, `mass*gravity`. The "weight of the displaced fluid" is the buoyancy force. Thus we are solving for

```
buoyancy = -(mass*gravity*fluid density/object density)
```

The negative sign is included because buoyancy opposes gravity.

Since `density = mass/volume`, the mass term cancels and we get

```
buoyancy = gravity*fluid density*object volume
```

We then exert the buoyancy force on the object by calculating buoyancy for each link and calling `Link::AddLinkForce`.

@scpeters has an alternative way of deriving the buoyancy force by thinking about the pressure exerted on the object due to the fluid, and it gives the same result. Ask him to explain this alternative derivation if you aren't satisfied with the math presented here.
values.title: BuoyancyPlugin for fluid dynamics simulation

summary.raw:

You can compare the effect of the BuoyancyPlugin on objects with different densities using [gazebo_models PR 140](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/140/added-submarines-of-varying-density) and the `underwater.world` included in this PR. One submarine will float to the top of the world, one will sink, and the other will stay afloat at a constant height (though it may spin due to its off-balance center of gravity). You should be able to get the yellow submarine to propel itself by using the left-hand menu to spin its propeller joint at a constant velocity. This is not due to buoyancy alone; the submarines also use the LiftDragPlugin.

The implementation uses Archimedes' principle, which you can read about on [Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buoyancy):

```

```

where "weight" is the force on the object due to gravity, `mass*gravity`. The "weight of the displaced fluid" is the buoyancy force. Thus we are solving for

```
buoyancy = -(mass*gravity*fluid density/object density)
```

The negative sign is included because buoyancy opposes gravity.

Since `density = mass/volume`, the mass term cancels and we get

```
buoyancy = gravity*fluid density*object volume
```

@scpeters has an alternative way of deriving the buoyancy force by thinking about the pressure exerted on the object due to the fluid, and it gives the same result. Ask him to explain this alternative derivation if you aren't satisfied with the math presented here.
summary.html:
This pull request introduces the BuoyancyPlugin, which simulates the force opposing gravity exerted on an object immersed in a fluid. It also adds some checks and cleanup to LiftDragPlugin.

You can compare the effect of the BuoyancyPlugin on objects with different densities using gazebo_models PR 140 and the underwater.world included in this PR. One submarine will float to the top of the world, one will sink, and the other will stay afloat at a constant height (though it may spin due to its off-balance center of gravity). You should be able to get the yellow submarine to propel itself by using the left-hand menu to spin its propeller joint at a constant velocity. This is not due to buoyancy alone; the submarines also use the LiftDragPlugin.

The implementation uses Archimedes' principle, which you can read about on Wikipedia:

object density / fluid density = weight / weight of displaced fluid

where "weight" is the force on the object due to gravity, mass*gravity. The "weight of the displaced fluid" is the buoyancy force. Thus we are solving for

buoyancy = -(mass*gravity*fluid density/object density)

The negative sign is included because buoyancy opposes gravity.

Since density = mass/volume, the mass term cancels and we get

buoyancy = gravity*fluid density*object volume

We then exert the buoyancy force on the object by calculating buoyancy for each link and calling Link::AddLinkForce.

@scpeters has an alternative way of deriving the buoyancy force by thinking about the pressure exerted on the object due to the fluid, and it gives the same result. Ask him to explain this alternative derivation if you aren't satisfied with the math presented here.

values.description:
This pull request has two goals:

* Allow a positive and negative multi-step while playing back a log file.
* Change the semantics of a multi-step. Now, when we set the `step_size` to 100, and then we step, what we observe is 100 individual steps. The new behavior is to observe in the client side only one step of `step_size` 100.

It will be connected with the GUI in a future pull request. Probably @chapulina will make the magic.

A few comments:

*  I created a new message `LogPlaybackControl` to control the playback. The message contains functionality for pause/play the log, step, rewind, forward or seek. This pull request tackles pause/play and step. The next pull request will implement the rest of the features.
* Stepping forward with big `step_size` or stepping backwards when you're far from the beginning of the log file is really slow.

When we have all the functionality working and connected with the GUI I'll probably make another pull request for using keyframes in the log file that will speedup the playback.

**Update**: While reviewing this pull request, we found that it would be nice to include in the log file the simulation `iterations`. If `<iterations>` is present in the log file, we should use it during playback and the world should replace its `iterations` value with the one saved in the log file. Two separate pull requests have been created to tackle this feature: 

   * https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/188
   * #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1722
values.title: Implement forward/backwards multi-step for log playback

summary.raw:
This pull request has two goals:

* Allow a positive and negative multi-step while playing back a log file.
* Change the semantics of a multi-step. Now, when we set the `step_size` to 100, and then we step, what we observe is 100 individual steps. The new behavior is to observe in the client side only one step of `step_size` 100.

It will be connected with the GUI in a future pull request. Probably @chapulina will make the magic.

A few comments:

*  I created a new message `LogPlaybackControl` to control the playback. The message contains functionality for pause/play the log, step, rewind, forward or seek. This pull request tackles pause/play and step. The next pull request will implement the rest of the features.
* Stepping forward with big `step_size` or stepping backwards when you're far from the beginning of the log file is really slow.

When we have all the functionality working and connected with the GUI I'll probably make another pull request for using keyframes in the log file that will speedup the playback.

**Update**: While reviewing this pull request, we found that it would be nice to include in the log file the simulation `iterations`. If `<iterations>` is present in the log file, we should use it during playback and the world should replace its `iterations` value with the one saved in the log file. Two separate pull requests have been created to tackle this feature: 

   * https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/188
   * #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1722
summary.html:
This pull request has two goals:

  • Allow a positive and negative multi-step while playing back a log file.
  • Change the semantics of a multi-step. Now, when we set the step_size to 100, and then we step, what we observe is 100 individual steps. The new behavior is to observe in the client side only one step of step_size 100.

It will be connected with the GUI in a future pull request. Probably @chapulina will make the magic.

A few comments:

  • I created a new message LogPlaybackControl to control the playback. The message contains functionality for pause/play the log, step, rewind, forward or seek. This pull request tackles pause/play and step. The next pull request will implement the rest of the features.
  • Stepping forward with big step_size or stepping backwards when you're far from the beginning of the log file is really slow.

When we have all the functionality working and connected with the GUI I'll probably make another pull request for using keyframes in the log file that will speedup the playback.

Update: While reviewing this pull request, we found that it would be nice to include in the log file the simulation iterations. If <iterations> is present in the log file, we should use it during playback and the world should replace its iterations value with the one saved in the log file. Two separate pull requests have been created to tackle this feature:

  • https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/188
  • #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1722

values.description:
This is another portion of the Windows port. Client applications were forced to link against the physics and sensor libraries because the application used `libgazebo.so`.

This pull request creates a separate `libgazebo_client.so` that can be used by client applications. It's now up to the client application to link against physics, if they need it.

[Trusty nvidia clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/82/)

[Trusty no gpu clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/122/)

[Homebrew clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/79/)

The revision number on these builds match the commit prior to the Update Changelog commit.

values.description:
Two tests are failing via timeouts on the dart build:

* [PhysicsEngines/HeightmapTest.Volume/3](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/48/testReport/junit/(root)/INTEGRATION_heightmap/test_ran/)
* [INTEGRATION_joint_revolute](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/48/testReport/junit/(root)/INTEGRATION_joint_revolute/test_ran/)

The heightmap Volume test was added recently, but it doesn't work with dart and causes the test to fail via timeout. This pull request disables that test.

The `INTEGRATION_joint_revolute` has been failing sometimes. When it passes, it takes about 236 seconds, while the timeout is 240 seconds. This pull request also increases the timeout for that test.

A [dart4 jenkins build shows these tests are fixed](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/47/).
values.title: Fix dart tests

summary.raw:
Two tests are failing via timeouts on the dart build:

* [PhysicsEngines/HeightmapTest.Volume/3](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/48/testReport/junit/(root)/INTEGRATION_heightmap/test_ran/)
* [INTEGRATION_joint_revolute](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/48/testReport/junit/(root)/INTEGRATION_joint_revolute/test_ran/)

The heightmap Volume test was added recently, but it doesn't work with dart and causes the test to fail via timeout. This pull request disables that test.

The `INTEGRATION_joint_revolute` has been failing sometimes. When it passes, it takes about 236 seconds, while the timeout is 240 seconds. This pull request also increases the timeout for that test.

A [dart4 jenkins build shows these tests are fixed](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/47/).
summary.html:
Two tests are failing via timeouts on the dart build:

  • PhysicsEngines/HeightmapTest.Volume/3
  • INTEGRATION_joint_revolute

The heightmap Volume test was added recently, but it doesn't work with dart and causes the test to fail via timeout. This pull request disables that test.

The INTEGRATION_joint_revolute has been failing sometimes. When it passes, it takes about 236 seconds, while the timeout is 240 seconds. This pull request also increases the timeout for that test.

A dart4 jenkins build shows these tests are fixed.

values.description:
Per #1555, I refactored example_plugins.cc and example_standalone.cc into examples_build.cc so they can share the testing code. I also enabled testing of all the stand_alone examples and fixed their compilation.

Note that one of the examples is failing on OS X, but this is fixed by pull request #1642.

values.description:
Per issue #1595, the user camera pose can be viewed from the `Scene` element in the gui. The components can also be set individually for increased precision. I also made sure that the pose field would be expanded when you click on `Scene`. It's always a pet peeve of mine that the pose elements are not automatically expanded in the gui.

@iche033 also helped me set reduce the size of the increments of the roll/pitch/yaw fields so the scroll wheel is more useful.

![GUI_camera_pose.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/853107913-GUI_camera_pose.png)

[Jenkins: trusty nvidia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/155/) is clean
values.title: Get/Set user camera pose in GUI (#1595)

summary.raw:
Per issue #1595, the user camera pose can be viewed from the `Scene` element in the gui. The components can also be set individually for increased precision. I also made sure that the pose field would be expanded when you click on `Scene`. It's always a pet peeve of mine that the pose elements are not automatically expanded in the gui.

@iche033 also helped me set reduce the size of the increments of the roll/pitch/yaw fields so the scroll wheel is more useful.

![GUI_camera_pose.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/853107913-GUI_camera_pose.png)

[Jenkins: trusty nvidia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/155/) is clean
summary.html:
Per issue #1595, the user camera pose can be viewed from the Scene element in the gui. The components can also be set individually for increased precision. I also made sure that the pose field would be expanded when you click on Scene. It's always a pet peeve of mine that the pose elements are not automatically expanded in the gui.

@iche033 also helped me set reduce the size of the increments of the roll/pitch/yaw fields so the scroll wheel is more useful.
